content.description: Climb the face on good knobby holds.
content.location: Left side of the north face of the 'Heavenly Path Boulder'

content.description: The right side of the High Road arete, climbed using left hand up the arete and right hand in an array of pockets including the high painful mono, then continuing up the right side of the arete.
content.location: Right of High Road, left of Heavenly Path

content.description: Climb the right side of the boulder following the arete to the top.
content.location: Right side of the Heavenly face

content.description:
The rock is a bit suspect, but the arete gives a good climb on big flakes.

Climb the arete direct.
Climb jugs to a large hueco/undercling. Pull onto the the slab for an exciting finish on crimps.
content.location: West face of the 'Heavenly Path Boulder' which will be on your right as you hike in on the main trail.  Lots of other nice easy lines can be found in the neighborhood.

content.description: Sit start low in the cave far to the left of Which Road on the Heavenly Path boulder. Do moves and climb directly up the face. Probably been done many times before, but it's not in charlie's book. Seemed like a happies V2.
content.location: If looking directly at the Heavenly Path, go left around the corner of the same boulder to the small cave feature. Far left of the other face climbs. There are jugs to start on and flaky bad rock for feet. Things in the cave will break, but aside from the starting foot features the rest of the rock is good.

content.description: Climb the middle of the wall on smallish holds.   The crux is low down but take care at the top.
content.location: Middle of the North face of the Heavenly Boulder

content.description:
A great link-up.

Start as for 'Cross Roads', but at the angle change where the slab starts, make a short traverse left into a nice cross-over sequence with deep pockets/finger-locks to meet up with the hueco and finish as 'Heavenly Path'.

Often overlooked, this is a great variation start to 'Heavenly Path'
content.location: West face of the 'Heavenly Path/Which Road Boulder'.

content.description: Starting at the slanting slot climb up onto the slab and finish it directly via holds that seem to magically appear.
content.location:
problem is between

Celestial Trail

and

Heavenly Path

content.description:
Start at a good sized hueco.

Pull up and onto the slab and follow it, via nice slab moves, to the top.

For the tick don't escape right onto the arete.

climbs.name: Better to Light a Candle than to Curse the Darkness

content.description:
Sit start deep inside the cave and traverse lefwards on good holds and past a dabby rock at your back. Grab a slopey rail with difficulty and make a big move for good holds at the arete or if limited reach use intermediates. A tricky heel hook could prove useful or it may spit you off!

Looks like an extended version could perhaps be climbed from even deeper in the cave at a few grades harder.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. There is a rock behind you as you traverse.
content.location: Good climbing in a cool location make this route one of the best to escape midday heat! This lonesome route is the single line on the boulder. It is located in the Candle Cave, a large boulder uphill from the Heavenly Path towards the East Rim.
